thread.section_title: Texas Longhorns News - Sports News for Dallas, Texas
thread.title: National reaction to Texas loss: Another kicker 'who isn't really a football player' costs team
thread.title_full: National reaction to Texas loss: Another kicker 'who isn't really a football player' costs team | Dallas Morning News

author: Nick Castillo
title: National reaction to Texas loss: Another kicker 'who isn't really a football player' costs team
text:
Redshirt freshman quarterback Jerrod Heard led a furious 20-point comeback against California on Saturday. The comeback bid fell short when senior kicker Nick Rose missed the game-tying extra point. The Golden Bears held on to win, 45-44.
Despite losing, Heard had a historic night as he ran for 163 yards and three touchdowns and passed for 364 more. His 527 yards of total offense is a school record.
Here's how the nation reacted to Jerrod Heard's performance and Texas' heartbreaking loss.
Cedric Golden, Austin American-Statesman: "Jerrod Heard gets what it means to be a big-time quarterback. He isn't there yet, but count me as one who can't wait to see him grow up at the position. The clutch gene isn't given to all, but the kid has it from top to bottom, from the retro high-top fade reminiscent of Kid from Kid 'n Play fame down to the sweetest feet in Austin."
Pete Thamel, Sports Illustrated
Texas scores to supposedly tie the game on a beautiful QB draw. And just missed the extra point. Wow. You never see that in that situation.
— Pete Thamel (@SIPeteThamel) September 20, 2015 Heather Dinich, ESPN: "PASS: Texas QB Jerrod Heard. No, the Longhorns aren't playoff contenders, but let's give Texas a pat on the back after what's been an abysmal start to the season. Heard set a school record with 527 total yards of offense and his third rushing touchdown brought Texas within a point with 1:11 left against Cal. A missed extra point has punctuated the season so far."
Stewart Mandel, Sports Illustrated
Texas lost in excruciating fashion, but Jerrod Heard still had 527 yards of offense. Texas has come a long way in 2 weeks.
— Stewart Mandel (@slmandel) September 20, 2015 Skip Bayless, ESPN
Once again a kicker who isn't really a football player costs his team (Texas) a game after it battles its guts out. I hate place kicking.
— Skip Bayless (@RealSkipBayless) September 20, 2015 On Twitter:
 @Nick_Castillo74
